awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Designing an Advanced Mobility Management and Utilization Framework for Enabling mmWave Multi-Band Ultra-Dense Cellular Networks of Future
awd_abstract_narration:
Harnessing millimeter-wave spectrum can solve the two long-standing, interlocked problems in mobile cellular networks: spectrum scarcity and interference. Therefore, deploying dense small-cell networks using millimeter wave and sub-5GHz spectrum is being pursued as a way to mitigate current wireless capacity problems. While advent of such multi-band ultra-dense networks may solve these two problems, it gives birth to a new challenging problem: managing user mobility efficiently and seamlessly in such a dense network consisting of cells of varying sizes on a wide range of frequency bands with entirely different propagation characteristics. As handling user mobility is essential in a mobile network, ensuring the viability of seamless and efficient mobility in emerging cellular network architectures calls for a shift from the way user mobility is currently managed. The overarching goal of this project is to trigger this shift by transforming mobility management from being a reactive to a proactive process by developing an Advanced Mobility Management and Utilization Framework (AM-MUF). This project offers strong workforce training in a highly sought-after multi-disciplinary skill set needed to conduct proposed research, while ensuring participation of women and other underrepresented groups, and K-12 outreach. The project also leverages collaboration with key national and international stakeholders in cellular ecosystems to: 1) validate the mobility prediction models with data from a live network; 2) evaluate proposed solutions on a full scale outdoor 5G testbed; 3) conduct field trials on a real network; 4) promote adaptation of the project outcomes by 5G standardization bodies through a testbed-based demonstration of results.

AM-MUF will be developed through three interlinked research thrusts: 1) First, the project will develop practically implementable models for predicting a range of attributes of user mobility in ultra-dense multi-band networks; 2) Second, the prediction models will be leveraged to develop agile and scalable next generation solutions, algorithms and protocols for proactive mobility-based robust optimization and proactive mobility-based load balancing; 3) Third, the project will derive: the fundamental limits of accuracy of the prediction algorithms under different system configurations including cell density and mobility scenarios; and performance bounds of the developed solutions for a given prediction accuracy. To achieve this ambitious goal, the researchers will leverage a systematic methodology consisting of analytical modeling, system level simulations, synthetic data based training and testing, real data based validation, a full scale 5G test-bed based evaluations and field trials on a real network.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to seamlessly support user mobility has been the key factor behind the wide scale applications of the wireless cellular networks in all aspects of modern human society.  However, the key enablers for much needed more capacity in emerging cellular networks such as densification, concurrent operation at multiple bands and harnessing mmWave spectrum render current mobility management paradigm inadequate for delivering the expected Quality of Experience (QoE) and resource efficiency in emerging cellular networks. This trend calls for a paradigm shift in the way mobility is managed in cellular networks. The ambitious goal of this project was to produce the foundational work for this paradigm shift. Over its four-year life span project has not only achieved but far exceeded this goal as indicated by IEEE international award and several dissertation excellence awards won by the project’s key outcomes and its direct impact on the cellular industry.

 

In terms of intellectual merit,  project has resulted in a large set of foundational contributions needed for  the aforementioned paradigm shift. These include methods to generate high fidelity synthetic training data while using small amount of real data as seed; low complexity and yet high accuracy user mobility prediction models; models to estimate future cell loads using only past handover traces;  methods to predict traffic patterns despite seasonal variations while using only small amount of training data, methods to solve large scale non-convex optimization problems using novel insights from data drive modeling, and first of their kind proactive automation solutions that can eliminate the large latency that plagues existing handover, load balancing, mmWave cell discovery and energy efficiency solutions due to their reactive nature. This reactiveness-caused latency removal can act a key enabler for Ultra Reliable Low Latency Communications (URLLC, a result that goes beyond project’s anticipated goals.   The crowing achievement of the project is an Advanced Mobility Management and Utilization Framework (A-MUF) that can enable the needed paradigm shift in mobility management by transforming it from being a reactive to a proactive process. A-MUF does so by making use of three sets of intellectual contributions resulting from the project: 1) New high accuracy and low complexity machine learning based Mobility Prediction Models (MPMs) to predict various attributes of user mobility and traffic patterns such as next candidate cell for handover (HO), time of HO, future cell loads. A distinguishing  feature of these models compared to the state of the art is that they can be trained with very small amount of training data;  2) Novel multi-objective optimization solutions that leverage the prediction to transform the handover, radio resource management, energy saving, load balancing and mmWave cell discovery into proactive solutions. A key distinguishing feature of these solutions is their ability to solve large scale non-convex optimization solutions by leveraging new insights obtained through the data driven modeling approach developed in the project.  3) Quantification of gains the paradigm shifting A-MUF framework can deliver, as function of the accuracy of the underlying prediction models. Results show that adaptation A-MUF mobility management not only yields significant gains in resource efficiency, QoE and energy efficiency,  it can play vital role for enabling URRLC-a next generation network use case that remains notoriously difficult to realize so far.    

 

The broader impacts of project include successful training of a diverse pool of three MS and three PhD graduate students. Most of these students won university level or international recognitions for outstanding research contributions such as Dissertation Excellence Awards and IEEE International Award for best solution at IEEE Green ICT Summit. Graduated students have already joined the top vendors and operators in nation and thus are already making direct impact on industry. For example, one graduate student who joined top cellular vendor in USA has already filed fifteen patents. As part of outreach effort, project has also resulted in training of a female African American undergraduate student whose work also resulted in a publication. For dissemination to key communities of interest including standards, project result were presented as part of keynotes, tutorials, invited talks, panels, and seminars at major venues in addition to broad dissemination through IEEE and open access publications. Project also resulted in significant new knowledge base that has been adapted in a postgraduate course at  university of Oklahoma. Project also provided opportunities for experimental teaching on NSF funded testbed at  the University of Oklahoma. Responding to the invitations, project outcomes were also presented through invited talks at campuses of top cellular network vendors and operators in the nation who have been interested in benefiting further from project outcomes. Finally, the project has resulted in a startup that has been founded based on the strong interest industry stake holders have shown to leverage project produced solutions. The start-up aims to further develop project produced IP for direct impact on industry e.g., by  bidding for SBIR/STTR funding.
